problem_text: A group G is a unique product group if, for any finite nonempty subsets X, Y of G, there is an element of G which can be written in exactly one way in the form xy with x ∈ X and y ∈ Y. Does there exist a unique product group which is not left-orderable? P. Linnell
answer: Yes, there does (N. Dunfield, Appendix B in S. Kionke, J. Raimbault, Doc. Math., 21 (2016), 873–915).
